newsitem.title: USA: Sandoz, Ciba-Geigy cleared to become Novartis.
newsitem.headline: Sandoz, Ciba-Geigy cleared to become Novartis.

text.p: The United States Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday agreed to the multi-billion dollar merger of Swiss drug giants Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz to become Novartis, if they meet certain conditions.

The FTC said in a statement that the two companies must license or divest several product areas -- gene therapy, corn herbicides and flea-control markets. The merger would create the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company after Britain's Glaxo-Wellcome.
Combined capitalisation of the two would be nearly $57 billion, with annual sales of nearly $20 billion in the core pharmaceutical, agricultural and nutrition businesses based on 1995 figures.
Analysts said Novartis would have a leading position in generic drugs, a broad range of healthcare products and clear dominance in crop protection products.
The FTC voted 5-0 to announce the proposed consent agreement, now open for 60 days of public comment. Typically, final approval occurs within two weeks after the close of public comment.
The FTC said Sandoz has agreed to license some gene therapy technology and patent rights to Rhone-Poulenc Rorer so that it can compete against the new combined firm.
Sandoz agreed to sell its United States and Canadian corn herbicide business to BASF for about $780 million, which the FTC called one of the largest divestitures it has ever required.

The Sandoz flea control business would be sold to Central Garden & Pet Co. of Lafayette, Calif., or another FTC-approved buyer. The new producer of pet products would be permitted to produce its own methoprene, the active ingredient in the flea products.
Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz said the required conditions would leave the innovative potential of Novartis intact.
"The required divestments and conditions will leave the innovative potential of Novartis intact," they said in a joint statement after the FTC announcement.
Shares in Novartis NOVZn.S were to start trading on the Swiss Exchange on Dec. 23.
